newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-BALD EAGLE, BARNSLEY AND ROY MAKE DEBUT DAY.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-BALD EAGLE, BARNSLEY AND ROY MAKE DEBUT DAY.

text.p: The bald eagle swept in triumphantly, Roy of the Rovers made a winning debut and Neil Redfearn made history to a samba beat.
It was debut day in the English premier league on Saturday, with a host of new arrivals eager to impress the fans and justify fat transfer fees.

Arsenal paraded Dutchman Marc Overmars, Liverpool had German international KarlHeinz Riedle and England midfielder Paul Ince back from Italy but none found the net on a day when the locals fared best.
Of the 21 premier league goals scored, only six were scored by the foreign legionnaires.
Three were in one match -- Newcastle's Colombian striker Faustino Asprilla scoring twice and Sheffield Wednesday's Italian Benito Carbone replying in a 2-1 defeat.
Arsenal, for all their foreign firepower, relied on Ian Wright once again in a 1-1 draw at Leeds while Coventry's Dion Dublin put three past Chelsea.
Liverpool's 17-year-old Michael Owen scored their goal from a 71st minute penalty. They drew 1-1 with Wimbledon.
All were made to sweat for their money on a blisteringly hot afternoon but few caused as much of a stir as a debutant in small-town Yorkshire.
Redfearn cannot boast world fame. He has not played in Europe or in a World Cup final.
But his ninth minute goal for Barnsley against West Ham guaranteed him as much exposure in Sunday's newspapers as many a big-name player.
After 110 years in the lower ranks, the small northern club had arrived in the top flight and Redfearn had scored their first ever premier league goal.
For the first half, the newcomers seemed to be headed for a dream start.
A mass of red and white balloons were released from the pitch before kickoff and fans among the 19,000 strong sellout crowd beat out a samba rhythm.
There was even a Brazilian flag fluttering in the stands, for no very good reason beyond wishful thinking.
Manager Danny Wilson, speaking before the match, had revealed that his aims for a club tipped more for relegation than anything else were high.
"Everybody seems to think that it's just survival and of course that would be fantastic," he said.

"But everybody can have a dream and my dream is for Europe. And why not? I'm allowed to dream like anyone else. If you set your targets low, you possibly only achieve that. I try and look a bit higher."
So do Barnsley fans, who could for a matter of minutes claim that their club was leading the premier league as the only team to be winning at that stage.
The euphoria was predictably short-lived, with the visitors equalising shortly after halftime and then seizing all the points in the 76th minute.
On Tuesday, Barnsley face newly-promoted Crystal Palace -- the south London "Eagles" who won on Saturday at Everton, as did fellow premier league newcomers Bolton, who triumphed at Southampton.
Balding Italian winger Attilio Lombardo, Palace's record signing from Juventus, made an immediate impact with the opening goal in the 2-1 win.
Despite suggestions before he arrived by some team officials that he could prove an expensive mistake, the Italian scored a fine first half goal and set up the second.
Lombardo had made little impact initially but he produced the final touch to a pass from Paul Warhurst and slotted past veteran 'keeper Neville Southall.

In doing so, he spoilt another man's party -- that of Everton boss Howard Kendall, architect of the club's success in the 1980s, who was making his return to Goodison Park for the third time in his lengthy career.
Up the road at Blackburn Rovers, the former Swiss national team coach and Inter Milan boss Roy Hodgson was also making his premier league debut.
Roy's Rovers won, beating Derby 1-0.
